title: as I wander through the graveyard
content:
I saw this stone, dating from 1833. The letters are lead inlaid into the granite.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080706172455im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/08_05_11%20025_6501.jpg)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080706172455im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/08_05_11%20028_5439.jpg)

Lettering to die for.

 [‹ Fonts at the End of the Nazi Era](http://web.archive.org/web/20080706172455/http:/www.typophile.com/node/45328 "Go to previous forum topic") [Stephen Fry and the Gutenburg Pess ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080706172455/http:/www.typophile.com/node/45262 "Go to next forum topic")
author: russellm

comments.content:
^ why i like the edit - I forgot how big the image was. sorry folks.

here, let’s try this:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080706172455im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/08_05_11_027_trimed_3576.jpg)

-=®=-

Verrrrrrrry nice! indeed.

And very modern(ish). Are you sure, the gravestone is from 1833? I mean, even if the first date of death was of that year, they might have replaced the gravestone later when addition ppl were added, e.g. 1923/24 would sound more reasonable for me (though I’m not an expert in American grave lettering, it seems me way to grotesque for early 19th century).

no - I read the date off the thumbnail. Where’s an eye-roll smiley when you need it? :o)

-=®=-

“1833” presumably typo for “1883”? Still nice lettering though.  
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_  
Ever since I chose to block pop-ups, my toaster’s stopped working.
